title: The myth of the original star-crossed lovers - Shannon Zhao

multiple-choice.question: What special skill did the youngest princess in the celestial court of the Jade Emperor possess?

options.label: B
options.text: She could pluck clouds from the sky and spin them into robes.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the Queen Mother grant the weaver permission to visit Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: To punish her for her disobedience.

options.label: B
options.text: To reward her for her exceptional weaving skills.

options.label: C
options.text: To allow her to find new inspiration for her craft.

options.label: D
options.text: To keep her away from her sisters.

options.label: B
options.text: To approach her and introduce himself confidently.

options.label: C
options.text: To tell him of the swimmer's celestial origins and her dream to stay on Earth.

options.label: B
options.text: She had to lose her ticket back to Heaven.

options.label: C
options.text: She had to forget her life in Heaven.

options.label: D
options.text: She had to learn to weave earthly fabrics.

multiple-choice.question: What did the weaver and the cowherd build together?
What did the bull implore the family to do before he died?

options.label: B
options.text: To keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need.

options.label: C
options.text: To build a monument in his honor.

options.label: D
options.text: To take care of his offspring.

multiple-choice.question: How much time had passed in Heaven when the weaver returned after living on Earth for a year?
What did the Queen Mother create to separate the weaver and the cowherd?
What event occurs every year, allowing the weaver and the cowherd to reunite?

options.label: C
options.text: The formation of a bridge across the Milky Way by magpies.

multiple-choice.question: In which regions do people tell similar tales of the star-crossed lovers and celebrate their annual reunion?

options.label: A

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They are destined to be the rulers of Digitopolis

options.label: D
options.text: They are destined to be the guardians of the city

options.label: B
options.text: The immune numbers defeat the vampire

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The underworld became a beautiful place.

options.text: Because he wanted to punish Demeter.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Persephone's return to the land of the living.

options.label: D
options.text: The gods' decision to make a pact with Demeter.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the earth when Persephone returned to the underworld?

options.label: A
options.text: It became fertile and crops grew.

options.label: C
options.text: It grew cold, dark, and unyielding, ushering in the winter months.

options.label: D
options.text: It became a beautiful and magical place.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Persephone's transit between the land of the living and the underworld?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked the gradual turning of the seasons and the bittersweet compromise between life and death.

options.label: B
options.text: It marked the beginning of a great war between the gods.

options.label: C
options.text: It marked the end of Demeter's powers as the goddess of agriculture.

options.label: D
options.text: It marked the start of a new era of peace and prosperity.

title: Can you survive the creation of the universe by solving this riddle? - James Tanton

multiple-choice.question: What is the initial scenario presented in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A particle of matter amidst a chaotic stew of forces, fusion, and annihilation after the Big Bang.

options.label: B
options.text: A sentient species of the galaxy sending emissaries to the core to pay tribute to the galactic seed.

options.label: C
options.text: A game devised by particles to annihilate each other.

options.label: D
options.text: A device that can detect the full sequence of cubes around a circle.

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of the game devised by the particles?

options.label: B
options.text: To annihilate all particles of antimatter.

options.label: C
options.text: To have one particle of matter remain.

options.label: D
options.text: To simulate annihilations in a circle.

multiple-choice.question: What is the strategy to win the game?

options.label: A
options.text: To insert oneself into the ring at a random spot.

options.label: B
options.text: To map all pairs of adjacent particles and find a safe spot.

options.label: C
options.text: To annihilate all particles of antimatter first.

options.label: D
options.text: To simulate annihilations in a circle.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the programmable device in the second scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect the full sequence of cubes around the circle.

options.label: B
options.text: To count cubes of each type.

options.label: C
options.text: To perform arithmetic and carry out simple logical commands.

multiple-choice.question: How does the device identify safe spots in the ring?

options.label: A
options.text: By simulating annihilations in the circle.

options.label: B
options.text: By running time backwards starting from one particle.

options.label: C
options.text: By performing a sum of matter and antimatter cubes.

options.label: D
options.text: By detecting the full sequence of cubes around the circle.

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition for a spot to be considered safe?

options.label: A
options.text: If the sum of matter and antimatter cubes is zero.

options.label: B
options.text: If the sum of matter and antimatter cubes is positive.

options.label: C
options.text: If the sum of matter and antimatter cubes never hits zero.

options.label: D
options.text: If the sum of matter and antimatter cubes is negative.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the "Russian doll" analogy in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It describes the process of simulating annihilations in a circle.

options.label: B
options.text: It describes the process of inserting pairs of cubes into the ring.

options.label: C
options.text: It describes the process of running time backwards starting from one particle.

options.label: D
options.text: It describes the structure of the galaxy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the "galactic seed" in the transcript?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It is the device that can detect the full sequence of cubes around the circle.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the ring of particles.

options.label: A
options.text: The particle of matter will annihilate with an antimatter particle.

options.label: B
options.text: The particle of matter will survive and become the last particle standing.

options.label: C
options.text: The ring will tighten and the process will repeat.

options.label: D
options.text: The game will end in a draw.

title: Can you solve the birthday cake riddle? - Marie Brodsky

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem the narrator is trying to solve?

options.label: A
options.text: The narrator is trying to find a way to light all the candles on the cake.

options.label: B
options.text: The narrator is trying to determine the giant's age by counting the candles on the cake.

options.label: C
options.text: The narrator is trying to find a way to escape the giant's feast.

options.label: D
options.text: The narrator is trying to decide what gift to give the giant.

multiple-choice.question: Why can't the narrator simply count the candles from the outside?

options.label: B
options.text: The narrator is too big to fit inside the tunnel.

options.label: C
options.text: The narrator doesn't have a flashlight to see in the dark.

options.label: D
options.text: The narrator is afraid of the giant.

multiple-choice.question: What is the narrator's initial strategy for counting the candles?

options.label: B
options.text: The narrator starts at one end of the tunnel and counts the candles as they go.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The narrator uses a pattern to determine the number of candles.

options.label: B
options.text: It's difficult to keep track of the number of candles.

options.label: C
options.text: It's not accurate if there are many candles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the narrator's revised strategy for counting the candles?

options.label: A
options.text: The narrator tests a series of hypotheses about the giant's age.

options.label: B
options.text: The narrator uses a pattern to determine the number of candles.

options.label: C
options.text: The narrator divides the tunnel into sections and counts the candles in each section.

options.label: D
options.text: The narrator starts at one end of the tunnel and counts the candles as they go.

options.label: A
options.text: The narrator lights the starting candle and walks forward a certain number of candles.

options.label: B
options.text: The narrator turns off all the candles and then turns them back on one by one.

options.label: C
options.text: The narrator uses a pattern to determine the number of candles.

options.label: D
options.text: The narrator divides the tunnel into sections and counts the candles in each section.

multiple-choice.question: What is the advantage of the narrator's revised strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: It takes less time to find the correct answer.

options.label: B
options.text: It's more accurate than the initial strategy.

options.label: C
options.text: It's easier to keep track of the number of candles.

multiple-choice.question: How does the narrator refine their revised strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: The narrator increases their guess by a fixed number each time.

options.label: B
options.text: The narrator doubles their guess each time.

options.label: C
options.text: The narrator uses a pattern to determine the number of candles.

options.label: D
options.text: The narrator divides the tunnel into sections and counts the candles in each section.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the narrator's refined strategy more efficient?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the narrator to reach high numbers quickly.

options.label: B
options.text: It's more accurate than the initial strategy.

options.label: C
options.text: It's easier to keep track of the number of candles.

title: Why do cats have vertical pupils? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the pupil in an animal's eye?

options.text: To control the movement of the eye

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate the amount of light entering the eye

multiple-choice.question: Why do house cats have vertically elongated pupils?

options.label: A
options.text: To see in bright light conditions

options.label: C
options.text: To hunt effectively in twilight conditions

options.label: D
options.text: To see a wider field of view

options.label: C
options.text: It uses the small differences between the images to judge distance

options.label: D
options.text: It ignores the visuals from one eye

multiple-choice.question: Which type of animals typically have horizontally elongated pupils?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows them to see in low light conditions

options.label: B
options.text: It gives them a near-360-degree view and sharp horizontal images

options.label: C
options.text: It helps them detect vertical movements

options.label: D
options.text: It enables them to see distant objects

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the pupils of nocturnal geckos?

options.label: B
options.text: They shrink into slits studded with pinholes in higher light conditions

options.label: C
options.text: They remain constant in size regardless of light conditions

options.label: D
options.text: They change color in response to light conditions

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: A pseudopupil is an optical structure, while a real pupil is an optical illusion

options.label: C
options.text: A pseudopupil is an optical illusion, while a real pupil is an optical structure

options.label: D
options.text: A pseudopupil changes color in response to light conditions

multiple-choice.question: Why do humans have round pupils?

options.label: A
options.text: To sharpen certain dimensions of vision

options.label: B
options.text: To see a larger picture in relative detail

options.label: D
options.text: To see in low light conditions

options.text: They are circular in the dark and remain constant in the light

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They change color in response to light conditions
